Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Achieving a scalable Earthquake Early Warning System (EEWS) with a sub-second response
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project achieves a widespread earthquake sensor network in the earthquake-prone regions. With this wide prevalence of the sensor network, this smart, real-time earthquake detection system can detect an earthquake within a second near an epicenter and notify the other users away from the epicenter before the shakings arrive, effectively creating an earthquake early warning system for society. This same infrastructure of the smart earthquake monitoring system can be transformed to detect other natural hazards such as landslides, volcano eruptions, mine explosions, generating larger social and economic benefits. With this technology, instead of some sparse seismic recordings that we have currently, we can collect dense earthquake data from tens of thousands of locations in cities, providing a block-by-block risk-assessment of earthquake hazards in cities. This dense data promises several orders of magnitude improvement in the current earthquake hazard maps and helps the first responders, catastrophic modelers, primary insurance and reinsurance companies, city planners, and building owners to better assess the earthquake hazard risks. The granular level of the risk maps has the potential to increase the awareness of earthquake hazard risk in society.

The proposed project achieves a dense and hybrid seismic network using smartphones, tablets, and stationary IoT devices. A potential outcome of this project is a next-generation Earthquake Early Warning System with a sub-second response that repurposes smartphones, tablets, and other sensors of a large IoT ecosystem for the earthquake sensor network. To achieve the performance under a second, a new earthquake early warning system that scales the massive data streaming from multiple sources, enables sensor and server communication in the fraction of a second, finally builds a new push notification framework to alert hundreds of thousands in less than a second.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR project aims to build a reliable, fast, and scalable earthquake early warning engine feed by the vibrational data from the MEMS-based accelerometers such as the low-cost earthquake sensors, smartphone, and tablets. 


This SBIR Phase I project is to develop a new earthquake detection engine that exploits parallelism and concurrency programming. The new code introduces a new generation of earth velocity model to improve earthquake detection. The preliminary tests during this SBIR project showed that the new model improved the accuracy of the earthquake detection for various real sensor data recorded from the other seismic network in the past. The fast, robust, and scalable earthquake early warning system is critical in the earthquake detection based on the low-cost accelerometer devices. We expect that this system pushes the goal of having the affordable earthquake early warning system further.

This SBIR Phase I project also addresses the heterogeneous system that is composed of different types of the sensor. We assigned a different fidelity weight on each sensor, a single earthquake detection can now robustly the handle of hybrid network structures, feed by other Internet of Things (IoT) devices, smartphone, and tablets. The sensor-weight approach significantly reduced the false-positive rates of the earthquake early warning system. 


An affordable earthquake early warning system can save the lives and injuries by giving a few tens of seconds before the shaking occurs. The potential benefit of such a system that it makes the individual move to a safer place and that it allows automatic shutdown or downgrade of the operations such as in gas&electric apparatus, transportation systems, nuclear and power plants, hospitals. Because we can build such a system at a low-cost, this earthquake early warning system implemented during this SBIR project can be a single most crucial earthquake hazard mitigation tool for the world.
